IH. ABOUT THE POET
Born 1886
Died 1^61
H.D.
Hilda Eoolittle is among the most skilled of the Daagist group of poets*
Bom in Pennsylvania, she vent to Europe in 19H and lived them for fifty
years, until she died. Although best known for her Daagist poetry, "H.D.”
as she was know, was a serious student of Greek Classical poetry and translated
many works into English. This early training provided her with the control and
objectivity which enabled her to produce some of the finest Daagist poetry. She
has been called "the glacial sappho.*
The Dnagists rose to prominence in America about 1912-1914. Many American
poets (Amy Lowell, Robert Frost, Carl Sandburg, Hart Crane, Wallace Stevens)
were attracted to the movement which embodied many of the techniques mid
characteristics of Japanese poetry. The Daagist precepts of using common
speech, being free in the choice <xf subject, experimenting with rhythm, and
suggesting rather than completely stating an idea, are all evident in the
poetry of H.D* Her best work illustrates the Daagist belief that "concentration
is the very essence of poetry"*
IV. VOCABULARY NOTES
greats
Shis word means big or large,, but has the additional implication of
special significance, importance, nobility. As used to describe the massive
waves 0? green water spmsffijg onto the beach, great suggests the imposing,
even noble quality of the sea.
rocks:
Rocks may either be small or large. Da this poem, of course, they are
are large. Stones and pebbles generally refer to rocks of relatively small
size, whereas*”boulders are large rocks.
sea:
Ohis word has many connotations which the word ocean does not. Sea is
an older word in the English language and suggests more poetic qualities than
does ocean which is a more objective, scientific word.
